user_error_text: My drive shows 'Disk structure corrupted and unreadable' and I can't access files
symptoms: Explorer shows corruption message; cannot open drive; CHKDSK prompt
cause: NTFS metadata corruption due to unsafe removal, power loss, or disk errors
step_1: If removable, unplug and reconnect the drive; try a different USB port or cable.
step_2: Run CHKDSK from admin Command Prompt: chkdsk E: /f /r (replace E: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot access, try connecting the drive to another PC or use a USB adapter.
step_4: Attempt file recovery by copying important files to another drive; use recovery tools if needed.
step_5: If drive is failing, replace it and restore from backup; avoid formatting until files retrieved.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: CHKDSK: Disk structure corrupted and unreadable reported read errors and bad sectors

verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: DiskMgmt: Disk structure corrupted and unreadable - Disk not initialized or unknown partition table

user_error_text: Bad sectors detected detected during backup
symptoms: Slow read/write, errors during copy, SMART alerts
cause: Physical media degradation creating bad sectors
step_1: Immediately backup important data to another drive or cloud.
step_2: Run manufacturer's diagnostic and SMART tools to confirm bad sectors.
step_3: Run chkdsk /r to attempt remapping sectors; monitor for increasing count.
step_4: If bad sectors increase, replace drive and clone data if possible.
step_5: Dispose of failing drive responsibly after data migration.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: DiskMgmt: Bad sectors detected - Disk not initialized or unknown partition table

user_error_text: Partition table error / RAW partition appears and Windows suggests running CHKDSK
symptoms: Drive shows RAW or unallocated; partition missing in Disk Management
cause: Corrupt partition table or accidental deletion of partition
step_1: Do not format the drive if you need the data. Try to recover partition using TestDisk.
step_2: Connect to another PC and run partition recovery tools (TestDisk, EaseUS Recovery Wizard).
step_3: If recovery succeeds, copy data immediately to safe storage.
step_4: If recovery fails, professional recovery services may be required for critical data.
step_5: Once data recovered, recreate partitions and format drive, then restore files.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: I/O Error: Partition table error / RAW partition - Read failure at LBA 0x1A3F

user_error_text: CHKDSK fails to repair and I see errors copying files
symptoms: CHKDSK reports errors it cannot fix or crashes during scan
cause: Severe filesystem or hardware failure preventing repair
step_1: Run CHKDSK with /f /r and allow it to complete overnight.
step_2: Try running manufacturer's disk repair tools or low-level utilities.
step_3: Attempt to image/clone the drive to a healthy drive and run repairs on the image.
step_4: Use recovery tools (Recuva, PhotoRec) to extract important data from the image.
step_5: If tools fail, consult a professional data recovery service.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: DiskMgmt: CHKDSK fails to repair - Disk not initialized or unknown partition table

step_3: Attempt to image/clone the drive to a healthy drive and run repairs on the image.
step_4: Use recovery tools (Recuva, PhotoRec) to extract important data from the image.
step_5: If tools fail, consult a professional data recovery service.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: SMART: CHKDSK fails to repair - Reallocated Sector Count critical

user_error_text: CHKDSK fails to repair after unplugging the external drive without ejecting
symptoms: CHKDSK reports errors it cannot fix or crashes during scan
cause: Severe filesystem or hardware failure preventing repair
step_1: Run CHKDSK with /f /r and allow it to complete overnight.
step_2: Try running manufacturer's disk repair tools or low-level utilities.
step_3: Attempt to image/clone the drive to a healthy drive and run repairs on the image.
step_4: Use recovery tools (Recuva, PhotoRec) to extract important data from the image.
step_5: If tools fail, consult a professional data recovery service.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: CHKDSK: CHKDSK fails to repair reported read errors and bad sectors

user_error_text: SMART warning - Reallocated Sectors appears and Windows suggests running CHKDSK
symptoms: SMART shows reallocated sectors, early warning of failure
cause: Drive reallocating failing sectors; imminent risk of failure
step_1: Backup all critical data immediately — do not delay.
step_2: Run full SMART test (long/extended) using vendor utility to get detailed report.
step_3: Replace the drive as soon as practical and clone data to the new drive.
step_4: Monitor the new drive to ensure all data copied successfully and no further reallocation.
step_5: Do not continue critical work on a drive that reports SMART failures.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: DiskMgmt: SMART warning - Reallocated Sectors - Disk not initialized or unknown partition table

user_error_text: Drive not initialized after unplugging the external drive without ejecting
symptoms: Disk appears as uninitialized in Disk Management
cause: Partition table missing or disk metadata corrupt
step_1: Open Disk Management: if disk is uninitialized, do not initialize if data is needed.
step_2: Use TestDisk to try to recover partitions before initializing.
step_3: If data recovery is not required, initialize disk and create new partition/format.
step_4: After initializing, run disk check and restore data from backups.
step_5: If unsure, seek help to avoid data loss.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: SMART: Drive not initialized - Reallocated Sector Count critical

user_error_text: My drive shows 'I/O device error' and I can't access files
symptoms: Error copying files; I/O device error messages; transfers fail
cause: Faulty cable, port, controller issue or failing disk surface
step_1: Try a different cable, port, and connect the drive to another computer.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for disk-related errors and device issues.
step_3: Run chkdsk and vendor diagnostic tools to identify failing sectors.
step_4: If I/O errors persist, stop using the disk and recover data to another drive.
step_5: Replace drive or controller as required.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: NTFS: The file system structure on disk is corrupt - I/O device error

user_error_text: USB drive not recognized / corrupted — I get an error when opening the drive
symptoms: USB drive not showing in Explorer; prompt to format when inserted
cause: File system corruption or damaged USB controller
step_1: Try different USB ports and reboot the PC.
step_2: Use Disk Management to assign a drive letter if missing.
step_3: Run chkdsk on the USB drive or use recovery tools to copy files.
step_4: If drive prompts to format, attempt data recovery first before formatting.
step_5: Replace USB drive if controller is damaged.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: NTFS: The file system structure on disk is corrupt - USB drive not recognized / corrupted

step_1: Try different USB ports and reboot the PC.
step_2: Use Disk Management to assign a drive letter if missing.
step_3: Run chkdsk on the USB drive or use recovery tools to copy files.
step_4: If drive prompts to format, attempt data recovery first before formatting.
step_5: Replace USB drive if controller is damaged.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: SMART: USB drive not recognized / corrupted - Reallocated Sector Count critical

user_error_text: Read/write error during file copy and Explorer freezes when accessing the disk
symptoms: Copy operation fails with read/write error
cause: Bad sectors or transient I/O errors
step_1: Attempt copying small files to identify affected files/folders.
step_2: Run chkdsk on the source drive and target drive.
step_3: Use a disk imaging tool to clone the drive and then extract files from the image.
step_4: If specific files fail, try specialized recovery tools to extract data.
step_5: Replace failing drive if errors persist.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: CHKDSK: Read/write error during file copy reported read errors and bad sectors

user_error_text: Disk shows as RAW - Windows says the disk needs formatting
symptoms: Windows prompts to format drive; file system shows RAW
cause: File system damaged or partition table lost
step_1: Do not format; use TestDisk to attempt to recover partition and file system.
step_2: Try accessing files using a Linux live USB which can sometimes read RAW partitions.
step_3: If recovery tools fail, create an image of the disk and send it to professional recovery.
step_4: After successful recovery, recreate partitions and format the disk.
step_5: Always backup recovered data to a healthy drive.
verification: Drive accessible with files intact or successfully restored; CHKDSK reports no critical errors.
log_snippet: DiskMgmt: Disk shows as RAW - Disk not initialized or unknown partition table
